message: ‪Happy New Year, everyone! I hope you all had a safe and wonderful night as we welcomed in 2017. I'm excited to see what we can accomplish together in the coming year, and looking forward to getting started! ‬

As we’ve seen reported by the AP and other news sources in recent weeks, in 2016 the United Nations (UN) General Assembly adopted approximately 20 resolutions rebuking Israel, while only adopting four against all other nations combined (one each for Syria, Iran, North Korea, and Russia).  The most recent evidence of the UN’s bias against Israel came on December 23 in the form of Security Council Resolution 2334, which effectively states that the Jewish Quarter of the Old City of Jerusalem and the Western Wall – Judaism’s holiest site – are “occupied territory.” Sadly, the Obama Administration abstained from the December 23 UN vote, and the President subsequently refused to exercise his ability to veto the misguided resolution. Today in the U.S. House, however, we have reasserted the American people’s commitment to our friendship with Israel as we passed H. Res. 11 to call for full repeal of UN Resolution 2334. I regret that the action is needed at all, but am proud to support H. Res. 11 and all those standing with Israel.

Today we mark National Law Enforcement Appreciation Day, and I want to express my deepest thanks to each and every member of our law enforcement community throughout the Seventh District and beyond for what you do on a daily basis.  Your service ensures our security and safety, and so often at the cost of great personal sacrifice.  While we’re grateful each and every day, it is my hope that you all feel the support of your neighbors in a special way today. Thank you!
NA

In the last week alone, the House has made great strides in our work to whittle away at the often times well-meaning but punitive regulations that stand in the way of the thriving economy we all want. Examples include passage of the REINS Act just days ago to allow Congress to weigh in on executive regulations, the HALOS (Helping Angels Lead Our Startups) Act to provide much-needed clarity for our entrepreneurs and investors, yesterday’s passage of the Regulatory Accountability Act to add transparency to the process and limit costs, and today in the House we’re considering two additional regulatory relief measures. The 115th Congress has gotten off to a quick start, and through these seemingly small steps in the right direction we can get America back on track.

Today I’m managing rule debate for the House Budget Resolution, as well as the necessary action to allow for the confirmation of General James Mattis as Secretary of Defense.  Both crucial measures to move America forward, you can tune in on CSPAN or below.

Beginning with the broken process by which it was rammed through Congress, Obamacare has failed the American people, and today Congress took the first step to initiate the process of breathing life back into local health care markets.
"A genuine leader is not a searcher for consensus, but a molder of consensus." - Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. #MLKDay2017

Georgians are well aware of Governor Perdue’s heart for service, and I have no doubt he will bring that same spirit and commitment to this new role.  Having served as Governor of Georgia, whose number one industry is agriculture, his knowledge and experience in both the public and private sectors make him an excellent choice to lead the Department of Agriculture.  It makes me very proud to see the role Georgia will be playing in moving America forward, and I look forward to partnering with him.

Inauguration Day is always special for America, and that has certainly held true today.  The peaceful transition of power – irrespective of political party – is a lasting hallmark of our great country, and I’m excited to continue our work together in this next chapter.

Please join me in remembering our fellow Georgians and neighbors affected by the devastating storms yesterday.  If you’d like to help, you can learn more about the American Red Cross relief efforts here: http://www.redcross.org/local/georgia

As one of his first orders of business, today President Trump has reinstated the Mexico City Policy, which requires that any nongovernmental organization (NGO) accepting foreign aid from the United States cannot use the funds to either promote or perform abortions as a method of family planning overseas.  I’m grateful the President has taken this action in defense of life, and I’m pleased to see the policy reinstated.
The majority of the American people believe that those opposed to abortion shouldn’t be forced to fund it through the use of their tax dollars, and today the House acted on that belief.
The United States has no greater friend than Israel, and our commitment to its people must be unwavering.
Congratulations to the Seventh District’s own Dr. Indran Indrakrishnan as he continues his service to our community and state in this new role!

Today marks the 44th March for Life in Washington, D.C., and it comes just days after both the House and new Administration took action this week in defense of the unborn.  I’m grateful for all those who made the trip to Washington today – some from thousands of miles away – to stand up for those who cannot defend themselves.

By all accounts of his distinguished legal career, Judge Neil Gorsuch is exactly the kind of Constitutionalist America needs.  His record shows a passion and deep respect for applying the law as it is written – not as he wishes it to be.  His credentials show clear qualification to serve on the Supreme Court, and it is my hope that he will receive prompt consideration by my colleagues in the Senate. http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/316853-trump-taps-neil-gorsuch-for-supreme-court

The United States has no greater friend than Israel, and it was great to have Israeli Speaker Yuli Edelstein join us on Capitol Hill this week to discuss the many issues and challenges facing our two great countries. Our shared values provide a special bond, and I’m grateful that commitment knows no political party lines.

The Seventh District’s own Forsyth County is home to so many great folks, but most of us can’t lay claim to playing center for the very first Atlanta Falcons’ team. Bob Whitlow can, however, and I sure like his optimism! #Riseup! #FalconsFriday

It’s been a big week on Capitol Hill, and we’ve been fortunate to welcome world leaders and friends alike to discuss the challenges we face.  We didn’t just discuss challenges, though.  We also took some time to celebrate the National Prayer Breakfast together.   This tradition has become so much more than just a breakfast program, and it was in fact King Abdullah of Jordan who spoke to the crowd at lunch. We hear a great deal about what divides folks, but I can tell you there is much more that unites us. A strong friendship between the United States and Jordan makes each country more secure, and I’m grateful for King Abdullah’s commitment to our common goals.

I’m a big fan of what we do in the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee because transportation is one of those issues that brings people together rather than drive them to one side of the political aisle or the other. We saw proof of that with bipartisan accomplishments like the FAST Act and WIIN Act last Congress – both becoming law – and I’m confident we’ll see more of that success going forward. By working together, we can ensure America’s infrastructure is second to none. You can learn more by following the link below. #Building21

It’s been a busy and productive first month of the 115th Congress, and there’s more to come!  Please join me next Wednesday, February 15, for a telephone town hall meeting at 6:35PM! You can find details on how to participate below.

I have great respect for my friend Rep. Tom Price, and am proud to have worked alongside him in the U.S. House.  As a physician and a statesman, he is uniquely qualified for the role he now assumes as Health and Human Services Secretary, and I know he’ll bring the same dedication and commitment to service we’ve all come to know so well.

Even well-meaning federal regulations have a tremendous capacity to stifle economic growth and innovation, not to mention assume authority from the individual and the community. What I know from the success of the Seventh District is that accountability, growth, and responsible stewardship of all our resources doesn’t come from Washington. These are our shared values, and we are at our best when we have the flexibility to put them on full display.

Sadly, this comes as no surprise, but Humana has now become the most recent insurer to announce it will leave the Obamacare market at the end of 2017.  That means the majority of counties in Georgia will then have only one insurer from which to choose.  Irrespective of intent, and regardless of promises, Obamacare’s government-centered approach did not increase competition and reduce premiums – it has done just the opposite.  In order to breathe life back into our health insurance market, we must turn to policies that spur competition in the marketplace and empower the individual patient with real choices.  That’s what Congress and this new Administration – now including Georgia’s own Dr. Tom Price as Health and Human Services Secretary – is committed to doing.

Sadly, the legacy of Obamacare is its broken promises.  From “if you like your plan, you can keep your plan,” to “if you like your doctor, you can keep your doctor,” to skyrocketing premiums and exorbitant deductibles when the exact opposite was promised, it has not lived up to what was sold to the American people.  We now have an opportunity to take the Obamacare alternatives that have long existed in the U.S. House – such as the American Health Care Reform Act, the Empowering Patients First Act, the Health Care Freedom Act, and the House Better Way proposal – and turn those ideas into tangible solutions for American families.
Happy #presidentsday to you all!

From the American Health Care Reform Act, the Empowering Patients First Act, the Health Care Freedom Act, the House Better Way proposal, and more, alternatives to the federal mandates and “government-knows-best” model of Obamacare are all on the table for all to see.  We now have an opportunity to explore these ideas and coalesce around tangible solutions for American families.

I’ve always known our community to be filled with folks who see a problem and work tirelessly to offer solutions – and there’s no better example than the Georgia Manufacturing Alliance. Thanks again for all you do, and Congratulations!

“We’re always looking for a place to make a difference.”    I can’t think of a better phrase to capture the spirit of our community.  If you haven’t already, I hope you’ll read this great story of service and leadership.

Tonight, we heard the President describe his promises in a positive, bold vision for tackling the big challenges we as Americans are facing together.  From ensuring the safety and security of our great country, to providing a patient-centered health care system that offers affordable choices for all Americans, to a tax code that unleashes the power of the American economy, nothing is beyond the grasp of the American people and our great nation when we work together.

The Waters of the U.S. (WOTUS) Rule has been a point of contention since President Obama signed it in 2015 – including a nation-wide stay due to legal challenges and a House vote to repeal it in 2016.  The rule expanded the EPA’s authority such that even the smallest stream or pond could be declared a federal waterway.  The federal expansion created confusion and concern across the country, and it has certainly had an impact on folks right here in Georgia. I was among those who voted to repeal this misguided rule last year, and I am pleased to see the new Administration reviewing it now.

Today in the House we passed two new bills to combat the excessive growth of federal regulation in recent years.  Both H.R. 998, the “Searching for and Cutting Regulations that are Unnecessarily Burdensome (SCRUB) Act,” and H.R. 1009, the “Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs (OIRA) Insight, Reform, and Accountability Act” bring crucial transparency and accountability measures to the rule-making process while requiring that existing regulations be clearly beneficial – in current practice, not just name or intent – to the American people and economy.  Efficient and effective regulation is a necessity, but inefficient, needlessly costly, or obsolete regulations are a drain on the American economy and have been for far too long. Together, we are making a difference.

Congratulations to Ms. Debi West of North Gwinnett High School for being named the Southeastern Secondary Art Educator of the Year by the National Art Education Association!  Thank you for all you do for our community!

The Georgia Attorney General’s office is alerting Georgians of an email scam that claims to be from the Department of Consumer Affairs.  As you’ll see in the article below, the emails are not authentic, and have affected residents in Georgia and South Carolina to this point, so please be cautious with any such notices and hyperlinks that may show up in your inbox.

Today in the House we approved the Department of Defense Appropriations Act to ensure those working to keep America safe have the vital resources they need, as well as taking another step towards the regular order our Founders intended.  National defense and those who sacrifice to provide it are certainly on the common ground we seek, and I hope the Senate will follow suit quickly so we can send this legislation to the President for signature.

Please join me this Tuesday evening at 7:30PM for a telephone town hall meeting to discuss the most recent business on Capitol Hill.  You can find all the information you'll need to join the call below.

Today the House approved two pieces of legislation focused on protecting America’s veterans – H.R. 1181 (Veterans 2nd Amendment Protection Act) and H.R. 1259 (VA Accountability First Act) – and bringing accountability to the VA.  Ensuring that veterans and those serving them have the necessary processes in place to prioritize their rights, but also demanding accountability at every level, is a shared goal irrespective of politics, and these bills are important steps towards accomplishing it.

Yesterday the House passed a bill to improve the process through which unsatisfactory employees are removed from the VA.  Equally as important as it is to remove the bad actors, we must also be able to recruit, train, and retain quality doctors and employees to serve our veterans; and that is what motivated H.R. 1367, which we passed today by a vote of 412 – 0.  Fulfilling our commitment to America’s veterans is absolutely a common ground issue, and today’s vote empowers the VA to achieve that goal.

This is a great story about what our community does best – working together to serve one another and get things done.  Our part of the world is undeniably a wonderful place to call home, and folks like those at Creative Enterprises and the South Forsyth Rotary Club are why.  Thank you for leading by example, and for all the great work you’re doing!

As you have likely heard dozens and dozens of times in the last 72 hours, the House pulled the American Health Care Act (AHCA) bill from the floor when it became apparent that the bill would not have enough votes to pass.  President Trump was all-in, and I was all-in, but we simply couldn’t find enough votes in the House to pass it.    I believed—and still believe—that this bill represented America’s best opportunity to: (1) save the individual health care market from the destructive death spiral in which it is trapped with Obamacare, (2) escape one-size-fits-all federal solutions and provide complete flexibility to Georgia and other states to craft a Medicaid safety net program that can make an even more powerful difference for its citizens in crisis, and (3) repeal as many of the economically damaging and innovation-draining Obamacare taxes, penalties, and mandates as possible through the “reconciliation process.”  To read more on this process and sign up for my weekly newsletter, please follow the link below.
All who knew Jon Richards are better for it.  His is certainly a life to be celebrated.

Each year I have the pleasure of nominating some of the brightest young people in the Seventh District to America’s Service Academies.  Academy Day is a wonderful opportunity for those interested in military service leadership to learn more and begin the process.  Don’t forget to register at http://isakson.senate.gov by April 17 at 5PM!

We all want to be responsible stewards of our natural resources, and common sense regulation is a vital part of accomplishing that goal.  We also want to ensure every regulation is based upon sound, publicly available information to guarantee transparency in the rule-making process.  That’s exactly what H.R. 1430, the “Honest and Open New EPA Science Treatment (HONEST) Act” does.  I was proud to bring this bill to the floor yesterday, and I was proud to support its passage on the House floor today. This bill moves us closer to that important goal of protecting our environment in ways that are consistent with facts rather than political agendas – irrespective of who is in the White House.

The North Korean regime has shown itself time and again to be untrustworthy and aggressive with its own people as well as with others on the world stage.  Led by an erratic dictator who is blatantly pursuing intercontinental ballistic missile technology, we must recognize the alarming behavior in order to properly address it.  Last night, I presided over the House as we passed two measures to do just that.  H.R. 479, the “North Korea State Sponsor of Terrorism Designation Act,” requires the State Department to submit a report to Congress determining if the North Korean government meets the criteria of a state sponsor of terrorism, and H.Res. 92 formally condemns North Korea’s development of intercontinental ballistic missiles. Governments such as North Korea’s engaging in unacceptable behavior must be held accountable, and the broad bipartisan support of these measures is a crucial step in that process.
There’s lots going on in communities across Metro Atlanta, and the Seventh District – as usual – is right there in the thick of it!

Sadly this is not surprising, but it is concerning.  Just today, the AJC reported that Blue Cross Blue Shield may be the next to announce it is leaving the Obamacare exchanges, furthering the alarming pattern and “death spiral” of the insurance market under Obamacare policies.  As it stands, BCBS is the only exchange health insurer in 96 of Georgia’s 159 counties, and in BCBS’ absence, much of rural Georgia would be left without any option at all.  It is not a question of whether we should act; we must.  The right thing to do is to act before more families are crushed under Obamacare’s collapse, and I remain committed to building the necessary consensus to reach that goal.

This Congress is committed to rolling back excessive regulations that have been limiting economic growth for years, and in fact, 12 last-minute, burdensome regulations put in place by the outgoing Obama Administration have been fully repealed under the Congressional Review Act to this point, and three more have been passed by the House.  We’ve also passed additional legislation to help grow our economy. Today, for example, the House acted to empower America’s entrepreneurs by passing H.R. 1219, the “Supporting America’s Innovators Act” to increase the number of investors allowed in venture capitalist funds from 100 to 250.  When entrepreneurs take risks and are successful, the result is a thriving economy and job growth.  Seemingly simple measures like H.R. 1219, which passed with overwhelming bipartisan support, help us get there.

Today, Judge Neil Gorsuch was confirmed by the Senate as an Associate Judge on the United States Supreme Court, and I believe he will be a strong advocate for the Constitution, as well as a thoughtful jurist. His remarkable record and sterling qualifications reflect his intellect, character, and commitment to the law – as it is written, not how he may wish it to be.  I congratulate him on his confirmation, and thank him for his willingness to serve our great country.

When we talk about the need to streamline federal regulations, there’s no better example than transportation and infrastructure projects.  We can all agree that there must be efficient, effective processes in place to ensure public safety, but it is also crucial that we ensure America’s roadways and transportation system remain structurally safe and up-to-date as times change.  The regulatory chart below offers a glimpse of only a few of the challenges found at the federal level – not to mention state and local requirements – for those taking on these projects.  As a member of the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, I look forward to working with my colleagues in Congress as well as the Trump Administration to make this process more efficient and effective.

The message of Passover is one of hope through difficulty, and an enduring faith in a promise made.  It’s a reminder for so many to cherish the past and embrace the future.  As we enter this special time, I’d like to wish a happy and joyous Passover to all who are celebrating!

As part of the ongoing effort to make a leaner, more efficient and accountable government, the White House is asking the American people for their input on how to best accomplish that goal.  If you’d like to learn more about the initiative, as well as share any ideas you may have, just follow the link below.

Having visited the I-85 bridge construction site just this morning, I’m very encouraged by the progress being made already.  The incredible work began, however,  literally moments after the fire broke out with our first responders acting quickly and heroically.  I couldn’t agree more with President Trump’s characterization of these “amazing people,” and once again extend my sincere appreciation to these remarkable public servants.  You can read the President’s full remarks here: http://bit.ly/2p3Itfp
For so many, Good Friday is a time of gratitude and reflection.  As you mark the day with your family in your own way, I’d like to wish you all a wonderful Good Friday.
On this day we celebrate a promise fulfilled and the new beginning it offers. I hope you all have a wonderful and happy #Easter!

If you’re a young person in the 7th District and have an interest in attending one of America’s Service Academies, please come join us on April 29 at Dobbins Air Reserve Base in Marietta for a great opportunity to learn more about the process!  All attendees will need to sign up by April 25, though, so please visit https://www.isakson.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/service-academies to register.

Sadly, history often presents us with dark chapters, but in them we find crucial lessons that must be remembered and taught to each generation so as to not repeat them.  Today is Holocaust Remembrance Day, and we pause to remember those lost, and reaffirm our commitment to the defense of liberty.

Congratulations to former Georgia Governor Sonny Perdue for being confirmed as our next Secretary of Agriculture!  He’s long been a proven leader here at home, and will now be putting his experience to work in Washington.  Having been a farmer, doctor of veterinary medicine, and agriculture business owner himself, he is very much in tune with the needs and challenges of our agriculture community, and I look forward to the things to come under his leadership.

This Saturday will mark the 100th day President Trump has been in office, and as is always the case, this benchmark offers us an opportunity to contrast rhetoric with results.  The President outlined a bold vision on the campaign trail, which meant there was much work to do once in office.  While there is plenty of work still ahead, it has been a very productive first 100 days.  From the first confirmation of a Supreme Court nominee in that time-frame since 1881, along with a field of conservative Cabinet appointees including two Georgians (more than during President Jimmy Carter’s Administration), to enacting 28 laws – more than any other President since Truman – repealing 13 Obama-era last-minute regulations through the Congressional Review Act, to driving consumer confidence to its highest level in 16 years, Washington is moving, and I’m looking forward to continuing that work.

It was another great Academy Day here in Georgia, which unofficially kicks off our Service Academy nomination process each year, and as always, I thoroughly enjoyed visiting with potential applicants from the Seventh District.  We have such tremendous young people in our community, and we saw a record number of appointments for those we nominated for the class of 2021!  Thanks again to everyone who came out to make it another wonderful event!  I’m looking forward to seeing what this year holds!

Happy 69th Independence Day to our friends in Israel!  As an irreplaceable ally in the defense of peace and liberty, the bond between the United States and Israel is rooted in those common principles, and I hope you’ll join me in extending our best wishes for a wonderful celebration today!

It is a reality that Obamacare health care plans are failing and insurers are leaving the exchanges. Premiums for the few plans that remain are skyrocketing under the current broken system, and deductibles are often so high that families are effectively left without insurance altogether. Tens of millions more Americans have been left without any coverage whatsoever. We can do better, but we must act quickly before more families are harmed. This bill represents a thoughtful plan to keep the good ideas from the past, but also to start eliminating failed and damaging ones. The U.S. Senate must now act as Obamacare failures continue to mount and families continue to be left stranded. https://woodall.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/woodall-votes-repeal-and-replace-obamacare-restore-healthcare-options

The old saying, an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure, is certainly relevant as it relates to tensions with North Korea. Yesterday the House voted overwhelmingly (419-1) to impose stricter sanctions on the North Korean regime.  It does so by targeting their shipping industry and use of slave labor, as well as requiring the Trump Administration to report to Congress within 90 days on whether or not North Korea should be reinstated to the state sponsors of terror list.  If that next step is taken, even more sanctions and restrictions would go into effect.  There is no place for the unacceptable behavior we’ve seen from the North Korean dictator, and this bill is an important part of a unified response.

Governor Deal said it best – the way in which our community met this daunting challenge shows the can-do attitude of Georgians, and I couldn’t be prouder of the partnership we demonstrated throughout the entire process.  Literally, from moments after the fire broke out on March 30, to the bridge reopening in the next few days – over a month ahead of schedule – that success is a testament to what can be done when we work together, and most of all, a testament to the kind of people we have in our great state.

This is not good news, but it is expected news.  The reality of Obamacare’s collapse has already hit millions of Americans, and will continue to affect even more if we don’t act.  Insurers continue to withdraw from the exchanges, leaving consumers with little-to-no choice, and skyrocketing premiums for the ones that remain.  We can – and must – do better.  The House passage of the American Health Care Act was a crucial first step to restoring choice and affordability in the marketplace, but the work continues – in the Senate, in additional regulatory action to be taken by Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price, and in follow-up legislation to bring down costs, increase choices, and put patients in control of their health care decisions.
Wishing a happy Mother's Day to all the moms out there - especially my mom. I hope everyone is having a wonderful time celebrating these special people in our lives.

We can’t always choose the challenges we face, but we can choose how we react to them, and I couldn’t be prouder of how our community handled this entire process.  Just six weeks ago, an I85 bridge collapsed due to a fire at rush hour.  It caught everyone off guard, but yet, thanks to our remarkable first-responders’ action within minutes, not one person was injured, and in a month and half the bridge is completely rebuilt.  That’s an astounding accomplishment.  The seamless partnership between local, state, and federal leaders was exemplary, and I’m grateful to Governor Deal, Commissioner McMurry, and so many others for their leadership.

Following Peace Officers Memorial Day, and as we go through National Police Week, I hope we'll all pause to remember those who have made the ultimate sacrifice in service to their neighbors and communities, and thank those who continue to put the safety of others above their own each day.

As Americans, we’ve always been at our best when we’re building things – moving forward. We’ve shown time and again throughout our history that when we put our minds to something, nothing is beyond our grasp.  Here at home, I85 reopening over a month ahead of schedule is the most recent example of that tenacity, and while the circumstances weren’t ideal, the outcome reflects who we are.  May 15 – 19 is national Infrastructure Week, and it’s a time when American businesses, workers, elected leaders, and communities across the country come together around that shared principle, and as the last six weeks reminded us, when we’re united behind a cause, remarkable things happen.
Please join me tonight for a telephone town hall meeting at 7PM!  You can find all the information you’ll need to dial in below.

Tomorrow we’ll be celebrating Armed Forces Day to recognize all those who are currently serving – whether here at home or overseas.  If you don’t have plans and are looking for a fun way to remember these special people as well as participate in a great cause, I hope you’ll come out to the Cumming American Legion’s BBQ fundraiser to benefit youth development programs such Boy Scouts, Boys State, and the local ROTC.  It’s sure to be a great time.  As always, thank you to each and every military service member for what you do!

The driving force behind any good piece of public policy is always good public service, and this week I was proud to re-introduce a bill that is a result of the constituent casework we’re doing right here at home.  I’m always happy to go to work for individuals and their families on a case-by-case basis when they run into challenges, but when possible, the ultimate goal is to prevent those difficulties altogether.  That’s what H.R. 2595 seeks to accomplish, and I look forward to working with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle and in both Chambers to usher it to the President’s desk for signature.

You may not always read it in the headlines, but there are lots of seemingly small things being done each day in partnership to solve problems.  A great example is the Veterans Expanded Trucking Opportunities (VETOPPS) Act.  I introduced this bill, and it was subsequently signed into law, in 2015.  It removed bureaucratic barriers keeping veterans from returning to work in the trucking industry, and you can read more below on how it goes about that.  Just yesterday in the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, however, we unanimously approved a follow up bill that will help us serve even more veterans in a timely manner with the new streamlined process.  I’m proud to lead in this effort, and I’m grateful for the bipartisan support it’s received.

On Memorial Day we honor those to whom America owes a debt that cannot be repaid.  These American heroes from each generation of our history have always stood as the defenders of peace and liberty, and today we pay tribute to their ultimate sacrifice.  Words are never enough, but we once again come together to express our eternal gratitude to them – as well as the families left behind. Thank you.

The numbers don’t lie, and they tell us year after year that our community produces remarkable leaders.  Our Service Academy Appointee Salute is one of my favorite events for many reasons, but most of all, it’s a reminder of just how bright America’s future is in their hands. I was proud to nominate this great group of young leaders to our Service Academies, and I’m already hearing from those looking ahead to next year!  I hope anyone interested will not hesitate to contact my local office.

It has been 73 years since the extraordinary bravery and world-changing heroism of American Allied Forces on the beaches of Normandy.  Their courage turned the tide in Europe during WWII, and their sacrifice saved ways of life, entire peoples, and fortified freedom for generations to come.  We are forever grateful.

Whether in financial matters, health care, or more, consumer choice is crucial to a healthy economy.  Irrespective of intent, the Dodd-Frank Act debilitated Main Street rather than defend it, and it resulted in fewer financial choices for American workers and businesses.  It made the federal government larger and the small business owner smaller.  To the tune of one per business day – including some right here at home – Dodd-Frank has driven far too many local lenders to close their doors, taking with them an irreplaceable commitment to the men and women with which they share their community.  We can do better, and this bill is an enormous step in that direction.

Today, I joined President Trump, Secretary Chao, and Georgia’s own Department of Transportation Commissioner Russell McMurry at the U.S. Department of Transportation to continue the discussion on reforming and investing in our infrastructure across the country.  I’m eager to continue this partnership with Congress, the Administration, and our outstanding local leaders like Commissioner McMurry to ensure an effective and accountable process that restores American infrastructure to world-prominence. Here in Georgia, we saw elements of this approach in action during the I85 rebuild – and with remarkable success.  I’m confident we can replicate our success here in Georgia throughout the country.

Confidence among consumers and small business owners remains as high as we’ve seen in more than a decade, and the unemployment rate has dipped to 4.3%, its lowest rate in 16 years.  That is great news, but there is still more to be done to ensure long-term economic opportunity for the American people.  In recent years we saw the labor participation rate dip to drastic lows, and we’re still working to bring that number back up to where it should be.  A crucial step in that process is having effective programs and resources to develop our workforce.  From offering co-operative educational opportunities and apprenticeships, to tailoring education to demand-centered career fields, during Workforce Development Week these are exactly the kinds of discussions going on in Washington and across the country, and I’m excited to see what comes of the effort. #WorkforceDevelopmentWeek

There are a great many things on which we as Americans agree – irrespective of our differences – and delivering on the promises we’ve made to our veterans is one of those shared principles. I was proud to support this legislation which passed the House today with broad bipartisan support, and is now headed to the President's desk for signature.

Thank you for all of your concern and prayers. I was not on that baseball field this morning, but I hope you’ll join me in keeping my friend Congressman Steve Scalise, the amazingly brave Capitol Police officers who protected so many, and all of those injured in this attack in your thoughts and prayers.

Throughout America’s history – much like we’ve seen with the events in Alexandria, Virginia, today – we have had to overcome adversity, tragedy, and attacks on our freedom.  But through it all, those things that unite us as Americans remain.  Today we also celebrate the 242nd birthday of the United States Army, as well as Flag Day.  In both of these celebrations we find our American principles of freedom, service to others, and unity on full display.  The American Flag is the ultimate symbol of liberty, and the United States Army has been one of its primary guardians since its earliest days.  Today, we are grateful for both – and all they represent.

Today in the House, we passed two more pieces of legislation to provide the American people with expanded individual choices in the health care market.  They are the “Broader Options for Americans Act (H.R. 2579),” which would allow consumers to use a tax credit established under the American Health Care Act (AHCA) to cover costs of COBRA coverage, and the “VETERAN Act (H.R. 2372),” which would codify the current practice of allowing our veterans to receive financial support for a private health plan rather than enroll in VA services if they chose to do so.  Each bill is a targeted measure to address specific circumstances for the American people, and they represent the ongoing effort – phase 3 of our health care reform plan – to restore choice, competition, and affordability in the health care market.
Today, Speaker Paul Ryan signed landmark VA reform legislation to help ensure our veterans are getting the care they deserve. It's now headed to The White House.
Today, the #VAaccountability Act becomes law. This is a truly bipartisan effort to ensure our veterans receive the care they deserve. Tune in below to watch live.

Today in the House, we passed H.R. 2842, the “Accelerating Individuals into the Workforce Act,” which incentivizes states and industry to invest in their local workforce such that those who are looking for work can find it even sooner than they otherwise would.  By establishing a grant program to temporarily assist businesses willing to provide training and apprenticeship opportunities to our neighbors, we can help increase the rate at which those in need of assistance become independent.  I was proud to support this measure, and am eager to see it move forward to help families here at home and across the country.

Congratulations and best of luck to all our Georgia 07 cadets taking part in the JROTC Leadership and Academic Bowl today!  We're very proud of what you've accomplished to get to this point, and we're excited to see what's to come. Keep it up! #JLAB2017
With a lot going on in Washington lately, I couldn't be more proud of the work being done to better serve our veterans, and I'm very grateful for the bipartisan support.

Today, we’ll be considering the “Aviation Innovation Reform and Reauthorization (AIRR) Act” in the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, and I’m looking forward to a robust discussion.  Our aviation system needs the benefit of the innovative developments going on all around us, and the only thing preventing that is out of date thinking and government red tape.  This bill is a crucial step toward ensuring American leadership in aviation and making American skies the gold standard for safety and efficiency that all travelers expect.

The Obama Administration’s Waters of the U.S. (WOTUS) rule attempted to replace the judgment of Forsyth and Gwinnett County government with a federal bureaucracy’s, and that misguided notion was always the problem.  The issue is not whether we should protect our resources and be good stewards of the environment – we all agree we should – the issue is where that authority resides: Washington or here at home.  No one cares more about water quality in our community than those of us who call it home, and the Administration’s decision today gives us the tools that we need here at home to protect it.

Not all policy-making in Washington garners national headlines, but the reality is that there are a lot of seemingly small things we can – and do – work together on to make a difference.  A good example of this is an obscure federal regulation mandating that railroad employees cease work at a specified amount of hours, even if doing so leaves a roadblock in place until a new shift arrives.  We’ve had this affect our community, and it’s happening in others across the country, but there’s a clear solution. The article below is from February, and this week, I joined Representative Jim Sensenbrenner of Wisconsin to introduce legislation that restores some common sense to these scenarios.

“Liberty, when it begins to take root, is a plant of rapid growth.” - George Washington.   When we come together around our American ideals and principles, those things on which we may disagree seem to get much smaller and put into perspective. There's no better example of that than the Fourth of July holiday.  Happy Independence Day!

A healthy economy depends on many things, and the most recent numbers from last month show a strong trend in the right direction.  The U.S. economy added 222,000 new jobs – 43,000 more than anticipated by economists – and the labor participation rate increased to 62.8%.  In recent years, the amount of those who had given up looking for work – consequently not included in the unemployment rate – accounted for far too much of the population, but thankfully with new growth and optimism, they’re returning to the labor force.  From building on the regulatory relief already implemented, to moving permanent tax reform that provides certainty and opportunity for job-creators, and the list goes on, there’s more to do to ensure long-term economic strength, and I’m eager to continue those efforts.

Year after year, Georgia is ranked one of the very best places to do business in the entire country, and that doesn’t happen by accident.  It’s a result of the tireless efforts of so many.  Our ability to work together and build strong partnerships across industries and economic sectors is representative of who we are as a community, and because of that, the future stays bright!

Beyond all the noise most of us hear and see on the news these days, there is still a great deal that brings us together for a common goal, and this week in the House we took action on some of those very issues.  On Wednesday, the House passed three separate bipartisan pieces of legislation all aimed at combating the ongoing human trafficking crimes being committed across the country, and today we overwhelmingly approved the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA), which among many other things, includes the largest pay raise for our troops this decade.  These are both prime examples of the good, commonsense, bipartisan work happening daily on Capitol Hill.

It’s Made in America Week, and that means we’ve been joined in Washington by American business owners from across the country to showcase their hard work and expertise.  Today, the White House hosted this diverse and talented group of entrepreneurs – including the Seventh District’s own Okabashi Brands Inc.  They manufacture their footwear products in Buford, Georgia, and I’ve been fortunate to be able to see their operation first-hand in the past.  I was able to speak with Okabashi CEO Sara Irvani today – though she had a very busy schedule, as you’d expect – and as is the case with all our local manufacturers, I’m grateful for all they’re doing in our community. Keep up the great work!
This Monday, I'll be hosting a telephone town hall meeting at 7:45PM, and below you will find all the information you'll need to participate at that time.  I look forward to visiting with you!

This week, the House voted in an overwhelmingly bipartisan way to pass one of the most expansive sanctions packages in our history on the governments of Iran, Russia, and North Korea.  These accountability measures are a vital part of keeping the American people safe, and I was proud to support the legislation.  From illegally testing ballistic missiles, to funding terrorists, to intervening in neighboring countries, the leadership in these countries has regrettably shown themselves to be untrustworthy time and again, and I’m grateful for the partnership across the aisle to act decisively in America’s best interest.

Today in the House, we passed an appropriations bill (H.R. 3219) that gives those who keep America safe the tools and resources they need to be successful as we move forward in the appropriations process.  From the biggest pay raise for our troops this decade, to vital infrastructure reforms such as authorizing the EPA Administrator to withdraw the overreaching Waters of the U.S. (WOTUS) rule, the legislation is crucial to that process. There’s always more to do, but I’m proud of what we’ve come together to achieve on not only this bill, but many others.

While the Senate has been stalled on health care, the work continued in the House.  Today, we passed two important bills: a bill to authorize our intelligence community for FY2018 and a bill to improve the VA by (a) requiring new accountability for bonuses paid out to VA employees (Department of Veterans Affairs Bonus Transparency Act) and (b) to provide crucial funds to increase health care choices for our veterans (Veterans Choice Program).  These are both important aspects of the overall agenda we are moving through the House.  It is no secret that the Senate has struggled more to reach consensus on a number of issues, but it is my hope it will join us on these important issues.

The importance of strong partnerships can’t be overstated, even though the results speak for themselves without much fanfare.  I recently had another opportunity to partner with many of you regarding your concerns about the security of Lake Lanier, and together we were able to quickly move a solution across the finish line.  I’m grateful to those who took the time to bring this issue to my attention, and I very much appreciate the timely response from the Corps of Engineers.

Congratulations to Meadowcreek High School’s Tommy Welch for being named one of the top three finalists for National Principal of the Year!  Having had the pleasure of visiting Meadowcreek in the past and meeting with Principal Welch, I’ve seen first-hand the great work he’s doing leading an amazing team, and I couldn’t be prouder that others are taking notice as well.  Keep it up, and best of luck!

There is an abundance of amazing things going on right here at home, and irrespective of the field, we have experts in virtually every one.  Last week, I got to see first-hand the innovation being done by Applied Information to utilize intelligent transportation systems, and let me tell you the results are really impressive! I’m grateful to the whole team for taking the time to share their vision and expertise with me, and am looking forward to the ways it can benefit our community and communities across the country.

Congratulations to Susanne Lauda of the Seventh District’s own AGCO for being chosen as a finalist in the Georgia Manufacturing Extension Partnership’s Faces of Manufacturing!  Thanks for all the great work in our community and beyond, and best of luck!

Our community is fortunate to have tremendously dedicated professionals serving and protecting us on a daily basis, and the leadership of Forsyth County Sheriff’s Office Chief Deputy Grady D. Sanford, Jr. and those like him is vital to their success.  Congratulations to Chief Deputy Sanford for earning such prestigious recognition from the FBI National Academy, and thank you for all you continue to do for Forsyth County.  As recent events over the weekend remind us of the importance – and inherent danger – of the work being done by law enforcement officers here at home and across the country, I couldn’t be prouder or more grateful for these brave men and women.

From the highest consumer confidence levels in more than a decade, to record highs in the stock market, recent months have shown some very positive signs for the economy, and fortunately we’re seeing more of that trend.  The Department of Labor announced that the number of job openings for June – 6.2 million – is another record high!
Just in case you’re not able to be get outside to view today’s eclipse, you can still watch it live beginning at 12PM!

We’re surrounded by excellence in the Seventh District, and this week I had the pleasure of presenting George and Lisa Winton with the U.S. Department of Commerce’s Export Achievement Award for small businesses who have successfully expanded to new foreign markets. Winton Machine Company was founded in 1997 by George and Lisa in the basement of their home, and now has 30 employees working to design and manufacture custom machinery not only domestically, but in foreign markets all over the globe.  They do all this from their Suwanee location, and our community is better for their efforts.  Thanks to the whole team, and again, congratulations!

If you’d like to get a good look at some of the amazing things going on in the Seventh District and Forsyth County, this Tuesday is a great opportunity!  The inaugural 2017 FoCo Expo will be going on tomorrow, August 29th, from 4-8PM at the Forsyth Conference Center at Lanier Technical College, and is free to attend.  There will be 68 vendors from across the county, food and drink for sale, and events for all ages, so come on out and see what your community has to offer!

If you’d like to help our neighbors to the west in the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey, there are a variety of ways to contribute or assist.  You can find many of these below.  Such circumstances are always extremely difficult, and this has brought historic flooding to the state of Texas.  In the midst of tragedy, however, the American people come together to help each other like no other.  Whether through our gifts, donations, or prayers, may we all support those affected by this storm to the best of our ability.
https://woodall.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/woodall-releases-statement-presidents-decision-end-daca

No one wants to find themselves in need of an air ambulance, but if we do, the costs should be consistent with fair business practices and not take advantage of those who are already at their most vulnerable.  For that reason, I was proud to author an amendment to the upcoming FAA reauthorization to increase transparency, protect patients, and move more decision making from the federal government to our state leaders.

It has been 16 years since the horrific attacks on America that took place on September 11, 2001, and today we pause to pay special tribute to those we lost, honor those who so heroically served, and celebrate the freedom that endures.  Through great tragedy, Americans have always come together like no other, and in my lifetime that has never been more clear than with our national and our personal response to September 11.
As Tropical Storm Irma approaches, please exercise extreme caution and heed the guidance of Governor Deal and local leaders.  You can learn more about ways to prepare and assist at the link below.

Tonight I’ll be hosting a telephone town hall meeting at 7PM to focus specifically on the issue of national security, and I’m pleased to have General Thomas Spoehr, Director, Center for National Security, The Heritage Foundation, joining me as a special guest!  Please join us by dialing 877-229-8493 just prior to 7:00PM, and entering the passcode: 17849 when prompted.  I look forward to visiting with you!

It’s hard to believe, but the deadline to submit Service Academy nomination applications is almost here again!  This year, all applications must be delivered to my Lawrenceville office by October 6, at 5PM.  Each year, the opportunity to nominate the Seventh District’s remarkable young people to America’s Service Academies is an honor and privilege, and I have no doubt we’ll have another impressive group.  If you’re interested in this opportunity – or if you know a young person who may be – please don’t hesitate to contact Debra Poirot in my local office at 770-232-3005.

It’s been a busy week in Washington, and tonight we’re moving right along with the next event in our telephone town hall series at 7PM – this time focusing on foreign affairs.  We had a great meeting on Tuesday discussing national security issues, with special guest General Tom Spoehr joining us.  This time we’ll be joined by Mr. Michael Rubin, resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, whose specialty is the Middle East, Arab politics. Call in to 877 229-8493 just prior to 7PM and enter the passcode 17849 when prompted. I look forward to visiting with you!
I’d like to wish a happy and blessed new year to everyone celebrating Rosh Hashanah! May it be a wonderful time for you and your family!

A quick reminder that tonight at 7PM I’ll be hosting the 3rd in a 4 part telephone town hall series focusing on specific issues.  Tonight’s topic will be health care policy, and we’ll be joined by a special guest speaker from the Department of Health and Human Services.  You can participate in the call by dialing 1-877-229-8493 just prior to 7:00 and entering the passcode 17849 when prompted.  I look forward to visiting with you! http://woodall.house.gov/sites/woodall.house.gov/files/9TTHM.pdf

For the fourth consecutive year, Georgia has been named the #1 State for business, and it again speaks to the quality of our people and our partnerships here at home.  Whether at the local, state, or federal level, by working together, we’ve been able to create an environment where businesses can grow, entrepreneurs can succeed, and families flourish.  When our community speaks, others listen, and that is because of the tangible results we’ve produced.  Thank you for all you do to make that possible.

I’ve often talked about the importance of taking the wins within reach today so we can come back tomorrow and work for more, and the unified tax reform proposal from Congress and the White House is a great example. It’s a big step in the right direction, and will absolutely benefit American families and the American economy – and it’s not the end of the discussion.  There’s more to do.  As you know, I’ve fought for fundamental tax reform in the form of the FairTax (H.R. 25), but the White House isn’t on board just yet.  However, the White House is on board with its principles of simplicity, fairness, and the elimination of damaging taxes such as the Death Tax and business-crushing Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) – all of which are present in the proposal released today.  America has an opportunity to achieve once in a generation tax reform, and together that’s exactly what we’re going to do. You can read the full proposal here: http://bit.ly/2hy3RqG

Today has been a great day in the People’s House! First and foremost, together we welcomed back my good friend and Majority Whip Steve Scalise.  Steve’s strength has been an inspiration to us all since he was severely wounded on June 14 of this year, and his recovery is truly an answered prayer.  In addition to welcoming Steve back, we in the House also passed bipartisan legislation to further assist our neighbors affected by Hurricanes Irma and Maria.  H.R. 3823 provides crucial tax relief for those in the regions still grappling with the aftermath of these storms, and it encourages private insurers to join the flood insurance program. For all the talk of division we hear so much about, today is yet another example of the things we can do together!

Please join me tonight at 7PM for another telephone town hall in our series where we’ve been discussing specific topics and hearing from experts in those fields.  Georgia Department of Transportation Commissioner Russell McMurry will be our guest speaker tonight as we talk about infrastructure, and I’m looking forward to hearing what he has to say.  Commissioner McMurry led the remarkable effort to rebuild the I85 bridge in record time, and his leadership continues to be invaluable for the State of Georgia.  All the information you’ll need to participate can be found here: http://bit.ly/2wU671o.  I look forward to visiting with you!
NA

Today in the House, we passed H.R. 36 to protect the most defenseless among us, and I am proud to have supported it.  This bill doesn’t address all of the inadequacies surrounding the issue of abortion and the sanctity of life, but in taking action where there is consensus today, we’ve taken a very important stand for those who cannot defend themselves.

This week we’re making our way through the FY2018 budget approval process, and that means we’re one big step closer to tax reform.  Now it’s no secret that I’m a FairTax guy, and I’m excited to use this opportunity to bring it to the forefront of the debate. Implementing tax reform where the consensus is built upon the FairTax principles of simplicity, fairness, and economic growth is something with which all Americans can move forward, and I’m excited to do just that.  Learn more about today’s tax reform conversation below!
NA
If you or a young person you know are planning to submit a Service Academy nomination application to my office, don’t forget that tomorrow – Friday, October 6 at 5PM – is the deadline!

Today is Manufacturing Day, and it’s a time to recognize all of our fantastic local manufacturers for the work they do in our communities.  Just one of the many great examples we have in the Seventh District is Buford’s own Okabashi – which Georgia Trend Magazine has highlighted for the great things they have going on in everything from sustainability efforts and environmental stewardship to an unwavering commitment to remaining an American made product.  Congratulations!

This is a once-in-a-generation opportunity to deliver on tax reform for the American people, and we have a unified plan to get us there.  Learn more at https://fairandsimple.gop/?utm_source=reprobwoodall

While we were successful in passing legislation to repeal and replace Obamacare in the House, unfortunately the Senate was not able to do the same thus far.  Ultimately, these issues must be solved at the legislative level, but I share the President’s concern for the American families who through no fault of their own continue to watch healthcare become more costly and less accessible. It is my hope that this action will provide relief, and I continue to urge my colleagues in the Senate to pursue consensus on a long-term solution.

From the devastation of Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico to the tragic wildfires on the west coast, there are many who have suffered great loss recently, and last week in the House we took further action to provide them with critical and immediate resources.  President Trump requested these much-needed funds, and I know this funding will quickly receive the President’s signature.

From the Rotary and Kiwanis visits, local business visits, the opportunity to help deliver meals with Meals on Wheels in Forsyth, one-on-one meetings in my local office, and the opportunity to attend the remarkable Diwali celebration in Lilburn, it was a great week to be home.  Thank you all for your input and your partnership.

The opportunity for once-in-a-generation tax reform is knocking, and now with the Senate joining the House in passing a budget resolution to unlock that process, we’re answering!  You can read more on why I believe tax reform is so important, and how we’re getting it done here.

As Co-Chair of the Congressional Robotics Caucus, I’m fortunate to work first-hand with some of the brightest minds out there developing new technologies, including Forsyth County’s own GeorgiaFIRST, and today was another great opportunity at our panel discussion on the history – and future – of autonomous vehicles. Thanks to everyone who came out to join us! #robotics #technology

Holding the Iranian regime, Hezbollah, and its affiliates accountable has been a priority for this Congress and the Administration since day one, and today in the House we continued that work with the passage of 4 bills (H.R. 359, 1698, 3329, and 3342) that not only condemn such activity and support of terrorism, but also issue further sanctions addressing Iran’s testing of ballistic missiles as well as call on the European Union to follow our lead in fully designating Hezbollah as a terrorist organization.  Sadly, the Iranian regime has repeatedly shown itself to be untrustworthy as it continues to fund and partner with those engaging in terrorism.  Today’s vote is an important step as we work to further isolate and weaken terrorist organizations, and I urge the Senate to follow suit quickly.
NA

We are so fortunate in our community to be surrounded by remarkable people who know no other way but to help their neighbors in need.  I’m grateful for everyone at the Forsyth Senior Services Center and the Meals on Wheels program for doing just that – and all they do on a daily basis.  Their passion for service is truly inspiring.

Congratulations once again to our Seventh District 2017 National Blue Ribbon Schools that will be making a trip up to Washington next month for an awards ceremony with the Secretary of Education! We’re sure proud of the hard work put in by the students and educators to earn this recognition! Keep it up!

The State of Georgia has been named by Site Selection Magazine as the best state in which to do business for five consecutive years! That doesn’t happen overnight.  It’s the result of a lot of hard work by the remarkable people in our communities, and a longstanding partnership with our leaders.  Thanks to everyone who not only makes Georgia the best state in the country for business, but a wonderful place to call home!

The “Tax Cuts and Jobs Act” released today is to-the-point both in name and objective.  It is a vehicle to provide much-needed tax reform for all Americans while spurring economic and job growth across the country.  This bill is consistent with our unified tax reform framework that has been openly discussed for months, and as promised upon passage of the FY2018 budget resolution, legislation has now been produced reflecting those principles.  The work continues, however, as we look forward to an ongoing partnership with the American people before considering a final product on the House Floor.

With much of the talk focusing on tax reform yesterday, you may have missed a very important – and very bipartisan (307-111) – vote we took in the House as we passed H.R. 849 to repeal the Independent Payment Advisory Board (IPAB), which was an Obamacare creation.  The concern surrounding this panel of 15 unelected bureaucrats is that the legislation gave them power to unilaterally slash Medicare funds – and consequently seniors’ access to timely medical care.  This dangerous reality, and ill-conceived approach, has hung over the heads of Medicare beneficiaries for too long, and I was proud to join my colleagues on both sides of the aisle in voting to eliminate it.
Once again, thank you to our remarkable veterans, their families, and all those who made today's luncheon in their honor possible! Our community is so fortunate to have you! #service #veterans

In our community, we’re always grateful for our remarkable veterans, and that’s especially apparent as Veterans Day approaches. It’s a special time to honor these men and women, as well as their families, who sacrifice so much for us.  After a productive week in Washington that included House-passage of four bills to improve the level of veterans health care service (H.R. 918, 1133, 2123, and 2601), I’m looking forward to being back home and taking part in these celebrations, and hope you’ll join me!
A beautiful day in Forsyth County celebrating our #veterans! Happy #veteransday, and thank you all for your service! #ga07
So very grateful for our veterans and a community that honors their service. Happy Veterans Day to everyone who has served! Thank you! #veteransday

It’s an important week in the people’s House with the first significant tax reform in over 30 years on the verge of passage, but what may not garner as much attention is that today we also passed the Conference Report to accompany H.R. 2810, the “National Defense Authorization Act,” which includes the largest pay raise for our troops in eight years.  There is no more important responsibility than keeping the American people safe, and this bill is proof of the bipartisan, bicameral commitment to that goal – as well as many others.  I’m proud of the work that got us to this point, and I look forward to continuing that partnership on much more.
NA

This week, the annual Red, Blue, and You celebration was held at Coolray Field to recognize our remarkably dedicated first-responders who give so much to our community.  It was another success, and I'm grateful for all those who made this event possible.  To our first-responders, thank you again for all you do - often at great personal sacrifice - to serve and protect your neighbors! #firstresponders #redblueandyou #ga07
I'm very grateful for this amazing team of folks at Norcross Meals on Wheels! Thank you for all you do in our community! #community #ga07 #thanksgiving

Today is a very special day across the Seventh District and the entire country because Thanksgiving is more than just a holiday.  It’s an on-going part of our American story, and who we are as a people.  I’m grateful for so much, and calling a place like our community home is certainly high on the list.  I hope you all have a wonderful and Happy Thanksgiving!     I’d also like to offer a special message of gratitude to our service members and first-responders who are away from home and their loved ones today. Thank you so much for all you do for us! #thanksgiving #grateful

I’m glad to see today’s vote by the Senate Budget Committee to advance legislation reforming America’s tax code, as it is a crucial step towards sending a final bill to the President’s desk for signature.  I’m eager to see a vote in the full Senate soon so we can come together and iron out any differences with the House-passed version.  Please join me in urging the Senate to do just that.

Today, Speaker Ryan hosted an enrollment ceremony for the bipartisan 2018 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA), which is now headed to the President’s desk for signature.  We often hear about the things on which we disagree, but there are a great many things that unite us – America’s service members and our national security being at the top of the list.  This bill provides absolutely essential resources for our military and national defense, as well as the largest pay raise for our troops in eight years, and I’m proud of the bipartisan effort that got us here.

Today I had the pleasure of visiting with our Forsyth County Commissioners in Washington, and as always, I’m so grateful for their partnership.  Thank you all for making the trip, and thank you for all you do for our community! #ga07 #community #leadership

Today in the House, we passed H.R. 38, the ‘Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act,’ which I was glad to see address not only the reciprocity issue among states across the country, but also many of the Tenth Amendment considerations regarding the protection of states’ sovereignty.  The Second and Tenth Amendments to our Constitution are both integral parts of our Republic, and any legislation addressing one should be mindful of the other.

Tomorrow (Thursday) evening at 7PM, we’ll be discussing recent happenings in Washington, in particular, the status of tax reform. Please join me by calling in just prior to 7PM tomorrow.  All the details you’ll need to participate can be found at the link below!

The world changed on this day 76 years ago when Pearl Harbor was attacked, prompting the United States to enter World War II.  President Franklin D. Roosevelt called it “a date which will live in infamy,” and history has shown that to be true.  While many years have passed, we still remember those we lost on that day, and in the days and years to come.  And we honor the service and sacrifice of all those who fought for not only our freedom, but the freedom of people around the world. #pearlharbor #ussarizonamemorial
As Hanukkah begins this evening, I’d like to wish all who are celebrating a blessed time with family and friends! May it be a wonderful season marked by joy and peace!  #chagsameach! #happyhanukkah

Keeping America safe requires tremendous partnership by so many, and this week we saw the culmination of much of that effort.  On Tuesday, President Trump signed the 2018 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) into law – a bill that was approved by Congress in an overwhelmingly bipartisan fashion – and equips those who protect America on a daily basis with the tools they need to be successful.  Additionally, in recent days, we in the House passed two more bills to crack down on the Iranian regime’s financing of terrorism (H.R. 1638 and 4324).  The “Iranian Leadership Asset Transparency Act” (H.R. 1638), and the “Strengthening Oversight of Iran’s Access to Finance Act” (H.R. 4324) are both targeted measures to enhance the Treasury Department’s reporting requirements to Congress and the American people, thereby limiting Iran’s access to financial resources used to carry out acts of terror.

As a long-time advocate for the FairTax, which I believe is the truest form of fundamental tax reform, I’m pleased to see many of its principles of simplicity, transparency, and competitiveness incorporated into H.R. 1.  The ‘Tax Cuts and Jobs Act’ reduces individual rates, empowers our businesses and job-creators to be more competitive at home and abroad, and sets the invaluable precedent that consensus on big ideas is not only attainable, but also replicable, and I look forward to building on this consensus as we take on new legislative challenges next year.
Just a few of the high points since passage of today's historic tax reform bill.

We often hear about the things on which we disagree, but there is a great deal we as Americans share.  Today in the House, we came together to approve the "Jobs for Our Heroes Act" by way of a 418-0 vote! This bill has always been about crafting a common sense, bipartisan solution that provides more opportunity for our veterans, and I'm grateful for the partnership that got us to this point.

The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act – now signed into law by President Trump – has already had an impact on America’s economy, spurring employers to invest further in the economy and their employees, and this is just the beginning. Families come in many different forms, sizes, and circumstances, and this reform benefits those across the spectrum.
Congratulations once again to the North Gwinnett Bulldogs on earning the 7A State Title!  We’re very proud of you and all your hard work and commitment!

Wishing a Merry Christmas to everyone celebrating today! May it be a wonderful time for you and your family! We especially remember our service members and first-responders who are away from their loved ones on this day. Thank you so much for what you do for all of us. #merrychristmas
